We do the big family dinner and go to mass on the 24th, then on Christmas Day we just spend it lounging around eating leftovers and watching Christmas kinos

I've eaten at a 2 star and 3 star place. I thought the 2 star was overall better since it included a stay in the hotel and truly luxury experience. Here were the highlights:

>picked you up from the airport in a luxury car
>asked what sort of bedding you preferred before your arrival
>room came with fresh fruit, wine, nuts, bottled water, and you could take any of the books or things you liked with you.
>drinks and amuse bouche in the garden
>7 or 8 course menu with wine pairings
>drinks and coffee after in the study
>they shined my shoes before dinner since they had been scuffed up
>they organized private activities that were actually really reasonable to partake in. Classic car rentals, fishing excursions, falconry in the orchard, etc.
>and of course it was easily some of the best food I've ever had.

All in for a night's stay, the meal, the drinks, the activities, and an hour ride from the airport it was $1200 a person. Seemed pretty reasonable all things considered. Probably won't do stuff like that too often, but it was a fantastic experience.

I've been to quite a few Michelin star restaurants but can't always remember their names, DESU.

Some of the ones I remember:

Le Bernadin (NYC) - ***
Daniel (NYC) - **
Gabriel Kreuther (NYC) - **
Aquavit (NYC) - **
Jean Georges (NYC) - **
Gramercy Tavern (NYC) - *
Blue Hill (NYC) - *
The River Cafe (NYC) - *
Le Saint James (Bordeaux) - *
Le Gavroche (London) - **
Kitchen W8 (London) - *
Portland (London) - *
HIDE (London) - *
Brasserie Zedel (London) - *
Hakkasan (London) - *
Galvin La Chapelle (London) - *
Jose (London) - *

I dread to think how much money that adds up to. Most of these were dates with my wife but there is the occasional business meeting in there.

Now that I have kids, we very rarely go out to Michelin star restaurants as it is hard to justify the consooming. The most recent was Gabriel Kreuther before seeing a play on Broadway (Leopoldstadt).

My overall view is that *** and ** places can be overpriced and a bit soulless at times (but not always). I'm not really interested in all the bullshit food theatre you can get at some of those places. There can also be a typical consoomerist fight to secure a reservation, which is really just quite tedious.

Nowadays I tend to prefer * restaurants as they are often more low key (and better value).

posts.com:
I usually slow cook the stew then cook the rice separately afterwards.
The rice is better that way, you can't really make risotto in a multi cooker because it requires constant stirring- yes it absolutely will stick.

If you ever get burn in a non stick pan it's important not to scratch the pan.
Tip everything into another container leaving whatever sticks in the pot. scrape the burnt shit out/off with a wooden spoon, rinse the pot, put the good food back into it, add some water so it won't burn again

>>18729430
This shit happens to me when I try and make chili verde, it's because the sauce isn't thinned out enough, or is sitting on top. the instant pot required liquid at the bottom to create pressure, so if what you're cooking is too thick it'll trip the burn warning. I usually have to add anywhere from one to 2 additional cups of water or broth before its able to pressure cook.
Also, if it does thin out too much, just add a slurry of cornstarch to it after its finished to thicken back up.

>>18713841
I moved into a new house (new as in just built, not just new to me) early 2021. I did a low and slow cook of 2 racks of beef ribs in the oven, used a meat thermometer to ensure doneness. About 12 hours later came the worst stomach pain I’ve ever encountered. I could now smell traces of chemicals mixed in with my beef ribs and immediately threw the rest away.

I probably should have gone to the ER to get my stomach pumped but for every 2 hours of excruciating pain came 20 minutes of relief that tricked me into thinking it was finally over. All in all the first 24 hours were the worst but I was still on the mend 48 hours later.

When I put it together that the oven was clearly contaminated with something (I wouldn’t be surprised if it was even something like paint fumes trapped from the build process) I immediately put it on self clean mode and now I thoroughly wash every appliance or utensil prior to using it in a cook. It’s been almost 2 years and I’m afraid to try beef ribs again because I think the smell might cause my body to instinctively shut down.

posts.com:
I was very fat as a teenager. My cousin's kid was having a birthday party, and they were just chucking some stuff on the grill. Since there were a lot of people and they were all over the place, plates were placed out all around the house and the yard for people to grab food. Thus meant my parents couldn't really keep an eye on my consumption of food, like they usually do.

I downed 6 loaded hamburgers (as much cheese and bacon as patty), 5 bratwurst sandwiches, chips, a lot of soda, amd several slices of cake. Somehow I didn't actually feel too terrible in the moment, but just as we were leaving I started to feel queasy.

I had trouble falling asleep from the stomach ache. Eventually I did, but hours later (still in he dead of night) something inside me stirred violently and it awoke me. I had to rush naked to the bathroom and slammed my ass down on the toilet seat, where I proceeded to spew an ungodly amount of brown water from my asshole. This, combined with having consumed enough sodium earlier to have killed a horse, meant that as I sat there spewing forth a waterfall from my ass it felt like thick boiling poison was flowing through every one of my veins, a truly horrifying feeling. My stomach felt like someone was pumping it full of air to bursting point, and after that it happened.

Undigested chunks came flying out in an unholy cacophony. My body completely refused what I had crammed into it, and was just letting it all out. I spent HOURS on that toilet, not wanting to push because my asshole was incredibly sore and in tremendous pain, but needing to push because otherwise my stomach would act up and get stabbing pains. I unironically cried. After all the chunks had evacuated, I was left trying to push out a mostly clear, thick slime.

I washed my ass on the bidet (even the very gentle stream of water on my asshole stung by then) and I crawled back into bed teary eyed, feeling like what I can only asume violent anal rape by an elephant does, and passed out.

>>18713841
bad hummus...
was camping with friends and had cooked a big celebration dinner for something--Steaks, hobo pack veggies and baked potatoes on the campfire...all fresh and from scratch except for 1 thing--some hummus that LOOKED and TASTED ok, maybe a little sour, but not really OFF.
Just as we'd finished cleaning up,(quickly, as a big summer storm was rolling in,) the storm hit with a vengence--big fucking banger of a thunderstorm too.
laying down in my tent with the driving rain pelting the fly, All of a sudden, I got that feeling--you know, the tight, almost battery acid tasting tightness right behind your jaw? I knew I had seconds to get out for the inevitable technicolor yawn...
Wouldn't you know? the fucking zipper gets stuck, off track, a good 3-5 minutes of fucking around with it in the best of circumstances--and that rain is fucking coming down in BUCKETS.
PANIC....Sheer panic sets in, I can't hold my gorge back any longer...
I fucking ripped the tent door open at the zipper and stumbled out into the now hammering rain, puking all that excellent dinner we'd just eaten in all directions as I staggered through the muddy forest to get further away from the tent, so I didn't have a pool of vomit sitting right outside of it. I spent the next 15 minutes on all fours, purging my entire being until I could do nothing but dry heave with sheets of water coming down all around me...
I was fine in the morning, and was able to fix the tent zipper so that it would NEVER LOCK UP ON ME AGAIN...but that had to be the worst.
Only one almost as bad was burning through half a case of little kings playing the "minute game"I made good friends with the snails that night as I crawled around in the dewy grass under the full moon...good times.
btw, when I checked that Godforsaken CURSED HUMMUS the next morning, it was actually bubbling--so I know that was the culprit.
I still like hummus though, even if I always give it the hairy-eyeball if it's store-bought.

>whether this rule applies to all forms of cooking oil or not
It shouldn't. The reason for the olive oil restriction was because the traditional way to transport it was via giant oxhide oilskins, so the oil went into contact with animal products.
Hemp oil (for instance) was transported and sold in earthenware pots.

>>wine is not allowed but not alcohol in general, but only imbibed in moderation
That's dumb. If wine is restricted, then everything alcoholic should be as well, beer, cider, spirits etc. included.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18723005
I like a moka every once in a while. how are you making it? I make it by: boiling water, pour it into the bottom, pour in the coffee, assemble the parts twist tight but not too tight, put on the burner for medium or medium-low-ish heat. Wait for the water to steam through and pour out the top. It should be a slow pour from the spout and not a violent bubbling. Some sputtering will occur, I've never gotten it not to occur (and if it doesn't it probably wasn't hot enough heat to produce a good taste coffee). Once its done pouring out, take off the heat and use hot hands to disassemble it and keep the top part on a small plate. Pour and enjoy.

I wouldn't say my coffee ever comes out "sour". It comes out as they espresso-like brew that mokas produce. Usually stronger in profile/flavor/etc than something like a V60 or drip machine. Sometimes it's even a little sweet tasting, in a way. Does that sound anything like how you make it? I think most people 1. don't boil their water before hand in a kettle and 2. use too high heat when it's on the burner

I was given a copper V60-ish pourover a few years ago, something a friend made, and it does work great, but it comes with a few caveats (that I already knew from brewing beer)
1) You want to clean and dry that shit. Oxidized copper's ok, but copper salts are bad for piggy's digestion. If you start seeing verdigris (blue or green), scrub it off.
2. A warmup's not a terrible idea, but it's nowhere near as effective as it is on porcelain or glass, because the copper cools down (and also heats up) much faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember middle school health class covering the food pyramid and how even as a child it felt sketchy at best. It's turned upside its head in so many ways. Even going by its min serving recommendations results in ~2100 calories a day. 2s milk (488g, 293cal) + 2s beef steak (170g, 428cal) + 3s mixed veg (30oz, 546cal) + 2s mixed fruit (324g, 194cal) + 6s grain (174g, 660cal) = 2121cal.
It's a categorical simplification that prioritizes ease of sorting over nutritional impact. Consider the analogy: An exercise pyramid that categorizes exercises by dumbbell, barbell, machine, no weights / body weight, etc.. It's stupid.

The truest statement on food health is, and always has been, "Eat a well balanced diet in moderation."
What makes a diet balanced? Depends more on your body than anything else. Sometimes your body needs more of something or doesn't need as much of something. That need, or lack thereof, could be short-, medium-, or long-term.
If your body is low on an essential nutrient (protein, vitamin, acids, etc..) then eat more foods that contribute to that, preferably while keeping your avg caloric intake approximately constant.
If you want to lose weight you don't even have to change the balance of your diet. Just literally eat less of the same diet. Although, if your protein intake would drop too much I recommend altering the diet a bit to prevent that. That and regular exercise will help reducing your muscle loss as you lose weight.

Also for fucks sake, stop thinking of nutrition as something that has to be met every day. It's a rolling average over days, if not weeks. You don't need some crazy diet that has all of your essentials every day. Some days you get more of this and less or none of that. It's all about averages over time. If you really need breakpoints, use 3d and 7d averages.
When I wanted to lose weight I lost an avg of 2 lbs/wk over 4 months even though some days I had ~2500cal because I kept my avg daily intake under my target ~1500cal.

76$ is not great, but will cover most of your food needs if you don't indulge in fast-food.
In this case i would go with my go-to combination of chicken, peas, rice, egg and kale/broccoli.
As alternative jacketed potatoes with sour cream or cheap cheese is filling and gives you all nutrients you need. If you can afford, garnish with herbs.
Lastly, you can eat white rice with salt/butter and have some cod liver on the side. It gives you nasty farts but it's like 3 bucks per serving.
Avoid berries, red meat and shrimp. While delicious they are too expensive.
Frozen pizza can be obtained for cheap. While calorie dense, it is unhealthy to rely on it long term.
So yeah, it is possible but you might snoop out the best deals in your area.

>>18728681
Applying for disability puts you on a wait list for determination. This takes anywhere from 2-8 months based on location for a pretty much guaranteed denial. At that point some % drop out and the rest contact a lawyer and appeal. The appeal is just the same review done by a different person with a longer wait, this time between 6-12 months. It's also a near guaranteed denial.
After that you get the right to a hearing where you can actually present your case, which is where the vast majority of approvals occur.

>>18724046
I make my own bread and the recipe I use makes two loaves worth of dough. Sometimes, I'll use some of the dough to make them. I'll take a bit of the dough, spread it out thin on a parchment paper covered cookie sheet, and fill it with whatever I want then fold it up and seal the edges then turn it so that the seam side is down on the cookie sheet. I'll do that till the dough is used up. I then freeze them on the cookie sheet and double bag them in a zipper freezer bag. When I cook them, I put some butter on top and put them straight into the oven at 350. No need to thaw. I flip them when the bottom is golden brown and take them out when both sides are golden brown. The last bunch I made had cheese, a little bit of ham, green onions, garlic, and very thinly sliced green pepper in them. Pepperoni, a little bit of pizza sauce, cheese, olives, onions, and mushrooms are really good, too. You can make them into whatever you want. I started making them because a store near me sold already made pizza dough refrigerated in a bag which made them very easy to make but they stopped selling it so I started using my own bread dough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18723957
There are certain requirements for something to be legally sold as "bourbon", but they mostly have to do with the ingredients, proof, and aging process, so it's a little different from a PDO. Bourbon was historically made in Kentucky, but there's no law saying it has to be there. Jack Daniel's never called itself bourbon because it's made in Tennessee, even though it otherwise fits every definition of bourbon and could legally call itself bourbon. These days people don't really care as much since quality stuff is being made all over the country (not juts whiskey, but beer, and bbq, and any number of other things). It's still pretty weird for there to be a bourbon distilled an hour north of Manhattan, but that's where we are.

It's weird, Del Taco isn't really that cheap if you order their "featured items", but almost half their menu is small value stuff. I guess most places kind of used to be like that, if to a lesser degree. I really think what happened was that once apps and online ordering became more common than going inside and looking at the menu while you wait in line, people kind of realized that it was a much better deal to order half a dozen value items for $5 instead of ordering "combo #2" for $7 and get one item, a side, and a drink. Now every place has doubled the prices of their value menu while slightly raising the price of their big items to make it seem like it's still a good deal, when in reality they're essentially trying to erase the very idea of a value menu without anyone noticing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
15 minutes @ 500F, bottom rack
No pizza stone or steel needed.

I'm fond of the autolyze, no-knead method dough:
3 3/4c AP Flour
1 1/2c water (room temp, filtered if possible)
1 packet dry yeast
2t sea salt
2T olive oil

Mix it all up, cover it, and leave it out overnight or 12 hours at least.
Punch it down, divide into 4 dough balls. Use one for a personal pizza, 2 for a standard size pizza. Enjoy!

posts.com:
>>18729221
Huge outlay in terms of infrastructure, very hard to roster staff across multiple sections.
Expecting FOH to be cafe trained, bar trained and do the lifting in bakery is a recipe for disaster.

I used to work in a place exactly like that and it went under. Opening for 12 hours every day fucked the front of house staff, they'd get in at 6 to set up the cafe bakery and if we didn't have enough staff then they would end up doing 11+ hour shifts, they made mistakes because they were exhausted, most walked off the job after a few months.

Bakeries don't use wood fired ovens, it's horribly inefficient. Wood fired pizza is also inefficient so your really limited in terms of take away.
Alcohol sales carried our dinner service and if we took too many take away orders it fucked the dine in pizza. People who come to pick up pizza are often app drivers who won't hang around and will refuse to carry your orders.

The Turks get this right by using a modern conveyor oven, selling all manner of flat bread, and keeping coffee service to a bare, bare minimum. If people want some oat milk frappe shit tell them to fuck off and go to Starbucks, you can't compete with places like starbucks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18728718
In many European countries, it is common for beer to be sold at room temperature in grocery stores and other retail outlets. This is because beer is often stored and transported at room temperature before it is sold, and it is not necessary to refrigerate it in order to preserve its quality. There are several reasons why beer is traditionally sold at room temperature in Europe. One reason is that beer is often sold in small quantities, and refrigerating it would be inefficient. In addition, many European beers are designed to be served at cellar temperature, which is slightly cooler than room temperature. It is also worth noting that refrigeration technology has not always been widely available, and in some parts of Europe, it is still not as common as it is in other parts of the world. However, this is changing as refrigeration becomes more widespread, and it is now possible to find beer that is sold chilled in many European countries. In conclusion, the reason that you saw warm beer on the shelves in European grocery stores is likely due to the traditional way that beer is sold and consumed in these countries, as well as the availability of refrigeration.

posts.com:
It sounds like you have a lot of great options already planned for your kid's meals! Here are a few more ideas that you might consider adding to your list:
Grilled chicken or fish with a variety of vegetables
Baked salmon with a side of quinoa and steamed broccoli
Vegetarian quesadillas with beans, cheese, and sauteed peppers and onions
Roasted vegetables (such as sweet potatoes, carrots, and Brussels sprouts) with a side of brown rice
A salad with a homemade vinaigrette dressing and a variety of toppings (such as cherry tomatoes, sliced cucumbers, and sliced avocado)
A stir-fry with a protein of your choice (such as tofu, shrimp, or chicken) and a variety of vegetables, served over rice or noodles
A pasta dish with a homemade tomato or cream sauce and a variety of vegetables (such as bell peppers, onions, and mushrooms)
Baked goods, such as muffins, quick breads, or cookies (just be sure to include some healthy ingredients, like whole wheat flour, oats, and fruit)
I hope these ideas are helpful, and that your kid enjoys the variety of meals you have planned! Verification not required.

Don't forget lecsó - a pepper and tomato stew usually make with Hungarian sausage (Gyulai Kolbász for me personally) but most smoked sausage is a good stand-in.

There's fuck tons of Pörkölt dishes pörkölt just means stew. Beef stew is my favourite (marhapörkölt)

Have a go at making krumplis tészta, its easy enough to make, just need any smoked meat and some onion and potatoes.

There's also rakott krumpli, potato casserole, layered potatoes sliced boiled eggs and sour cream.

There's a YouTube channel called kitchen paprikash that makes traditional Hungarian dishes and a few desserts.

Pretty much all Hungarian stews and soups go well with rice and pasta if you can't be arsed to make nokedli.

posts.com:
What springs to mind as soon as we say Christmas dinner?

A roast, sides of mash potato and bread rolls, a plate of sprouts everyone passes around but never really takes for themselves, boatloads of gravy? Besides wine, eggnog, and cocoa?

If you’re thinking of a spread on Christmas cards and advertisements, you’re seeing a dominant Western feast, popularized by America and the UK.

While this combination of foods is characterized as the Christmas meal, other parts of the world have their own spin on the Christmas dinner table.

Here are some of the most interesting ones!

Japan
The result of an insanely successful marketing plan in the 1970’s, Japan’s annual Christmas dinner has to include KFC’s holiday party bucket. The finger-licking-good franchise is so popular; orders have to be made as far as two months in advance! Nowadays, the bucket of fried chicken is also paired with a Japanese Christmas cake – a light strawberry sponge with cream.

Interestingly, the cake also has American roots. Post World War 2 saw Japan in an era of Depression, and sugar was seen as a very luxurious item. With a handful of American soldiers remaining in Japan to aid in rebuilding efforts, the cake became a sign of the two cultures coming together and has remained a tradition for the Western holiday.

>>18728127
It is possible to cook all of these ingredients together in an Instant Pot, but it may not result in the most flavorful or cohesive dish. Here is one way you could proceed:

Start by seasoning the chicken drumsticks with your desired seasonings.
Add some water or chicken broth to the Instant Pot, along with the rice.
Place the chicken drumsticks on top of the rice.
Add the chopped zucchini, carrots, and celery on top of the chicken.
Cook on high pressure for about 20 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and the rice is tender.
When the Instant Pot is done cooking, use the quick release method to release the pressure, then add the frozen kale to the pot and stir it into the rice and vegetables.
Serve the dish hot, garnished with your desired toppings.
Keep in mind that this is just one way to make a meal using these ingredients in an Instant Pot, and there are many other variations you could try. You may want to experiment with different seasonings and vegetables to find a combination that you enjoy. It's also a good idea to be mindful of your overall intake of oils and fats, as well as sodium, when preparing meals if you have high blood pressure.

>>18729747
Burn warnings can be caused by a variety of factors, including insufficient liquid in the pot, food that is stuck to the bottom of the pot, or a malfunction in the pot itself. Here are a few things you can try to troubleshoot the issue:

Make sure there is enough liquid in the pot. The Instant Pot requires a minimum amount of liquid in order to reach and maintain pressure. For most recipes, you should have at least 1 cup of liquid in the pot.
Check for food that is stuck to the bottom of the pot. If food is stuck to the bottom of the pot, it can cause the burn warning to trigger. You can try using a silicone spatula or wooden spoon to gently loosen any stuck food.
Check the sealing ring and the float valve. The sealing ring should be properly seated in the lid, and the float valve should be clean and unobstructed. If either of these is not functioning properly, it can cause the burn warning to trigger.
Check for any visible damage to the pot or the lid. If the pot or lid is damaged, it could affect the pressure and cause the burn warning to trigger.
If none of these troubleshooting steps resolve the issue, you may need to contact the manufacturer for further assistance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18728749
The high end zojirushi models have induction on the bottom and sides of the pot, and an additional heater in the lid so the heat comes from every direction. Cheap rice cookers tend to be mushy at the bottom and get dry near the top for large amounts of rice.

One of the advantages of a pressure cooker zoji is that the lid is completely air-tight and mosisture-tight so it can hold rice for a day with no loss of quality or 2-3 days and still be pretty good.

I make rice every second day, it takes less than 3 minutes a pop and I can just walk over and scoop out hot rice at any time. Just wash one dish every two days, its unbelievably easy.

It might not seem like a big deal but pre-zoji I was storing rice in airtight contains in the fridge and then splashing it with water to microwave and shit and when you are doing that every day it really adds up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18728734
Instant pot pressure cookers do rice just fine, and can cook plenty of other stuff. Cheap, effective, and even better: the new ones have air fryer attachments. Get one to do it all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are many different types of cheesecake, and the best one for you will depend on your personal preferences. Some popular options include:

New York-style cheesecake: This classic cheesecake is made with a creamy, smooth filling and a graham cracker crust. It is often served plain, but can also be topped with fruit or chocolate.

Italian-style cheesecake: This type of cheesecake is made with ricotta cheese, which gives it a lighter, fluffier texture. It is often flavored with lemon or orange zest and served with a cookie crust.

Japanese-style cheesecake: This type of cheesecake has a lighter, spongier texture and is often flavored with green tea or other exotic flavors. It is typically made with a mix of cream cheese and meringue, and has a softer, more delicate texture than traditional cheesecakes.

No-bake cheesecake: This type of cheesecake is made with cream cheese, heavy cream, and other ingredients, and does not require baking. It is often flavored with fruit or chocolate and can have a variety of crusts, including graham cracker, cookie, or nut crusts.

Ultimately, the best cheesecake for you will depend on your personal preferences and tastes. If you're looking for a high-quality cheesecake, it's a good idea to seek out recommendations from friends, family, or online reviews, and to look for a recipe that uses high-quality ingredients.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18729069
It depends on a bunch of things, but mostly just what you're frying, how much you're frying, and the capacity of your fryer. Filtering the oil will definitely make it last longer too. For me it's, "is the food coming out not looking very good? Does it still taste good? If it tastes okay does it matter if it's a little darker than usual?" If it's just something like french fries I don't care if they get a little darker as long as they taste okay, but if I'm doing something like tempura I'll change it. Obviously if the food is coming out tasting off you should change it, but if it's frying kind of weird but still tastes good I'll typically wait until it starts smoking, or do it right before the weekend, depending on which comes first. I honestly don't really care about what kind of oil is used. Some people have a preference, but I really don't think it makes much of a difference.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. Put 3 eggs in bowl and scramble with fork
2. Add pinch of salt and grind some black pepper in
3. Melt a little butter in a non-stick pan and lower it to low heat once melted
4. Add eggs and stir with long slow strokes to keep the curds long
5. Turn off the heat when the eggs just start to come together, the eggs cook themselves at that point
6. Serve on toast with chives if you have any

Easy, no gimmick ingredients, just eggs. Just cook low and slow and take it off before it's cooked how you like it.

Mix about 500ml of ricotta with a large egg, some chopped Spinach, parsley, salt, pepper, garlic powder, generous amount of parm cheese.
Let sit in fridge for about an hour.

Par boil the large pasta shells juat about done. Cool them down, and stuff the ricotta mixture in them.

Then either make a simple marinara type sauce or use whatever canned sauce you want. And then top eith a good amount of fresh basil and more parm cheese. Bake in oven until egg sets about 30 minutes at 375.

>>18721888
>I'm going to cook a prime rib dinner for my family on christmas, what are some good sides to go with it?
Took advantage of the Publix prices last 2 years in a row and got a 4rib portion.
Think British, really.
Get a nice trifle bowl and your trifle laced with sherry soaking, macerating the berries and boozy, get it good and cold. This is your dessert of choice.
For nice apps, anything seafood is popular, from an old fashioned cold shrimp cocktail to some stone crabs. For sides, you want a seasonal soup course, or a nice salad course, your pick Gorgonzola on that salad or cheese tray. It's pretty chilly this year, so the steakhouse soups are okay, like french onion. Remember you will want some horseradish w/ sourcream, lemon and parsley to make it special.
I like a good pan gravy which is going to happen with coffee in the pan and a covered roaster, so will want mashed potatoes with that roast beef gravy (versus roasted). Fancymode, twice bake some big potatoes. Bake up your tray of veggies from mushrooms to winter squash, brussels sprouts, mix em! or like tomato halves with herbs and breadcrumbs. A casserole like creamed baby onions or creamed spinach to add another side. If your oven is crowded, you rest that roast under foil, and reheat the gravy, that's all. Use your burner to steam some green beans w/red onions.
Pro-mode is yorkshire pudding. I am a sucker for nice rolls too.
MUST HAVE, a nice raspberry jello mold with cranberries and oranges. Or some kind of grandma style picalilli. It just goes to balance your plate.

posts.com:
One classic option is roasted vegetables. You could try roasting a mix of vegetables like carrots, parsnips, and Brussels sprouts with a little bit of olive oil, salt, and pepper. This will give you a tasty and healthy side dish that complements the richness of the prime rib.

Mashed potatoes are another classic side that goes well with prime rib. You could try making a batch of creamy mashed potatoes or mixing things up with a more unique twist like mashed sweet potatoes or mashed celery root.

If you want to go with something a little more unexpected, how about a salad? You could make a simple green salad with mixed greens and a light vinaigrette, or go for something more substantial like a warm spinach salad with bacon and eggs.

Finally, don't forget about the gravy! Prime rib is delicious with a rich, flavorful gravy, and you can make your own by using the pan drippings from the roast.

posts.com:
red potatoes
wash and scrub
cut into 8ths, 12ths, 16ths, or 20ths depending on size
put into large mixing bowl
add olive oil, salt, pepper, garlic powder, optionally paprika
Toss to evenly coat
dump out onto foiled oven tray
bake in oven at like 400f for like 40m

You can try this in smaller batches to figure out your spice ratio preferences. I typically use only a little salt, a a good amount of garlic powder, and enough pepper that my family tells me to make them with less pepper.

posts.com:
Ghee has a high smoke point and a nutty, slightly sweet flavor, which makes it a good choice for sautéing and frying. It is also lactose-free, which makes it a good option for people who are lactose intolerant or have a sensitivity to dairy products.

In baking, ghee can be used in place of butter in some recipes. However, it may affect the texture and flavor of the final product, so it is best to experiment with small amounts and see how it works in your specific recipe. Ghee is more suited to savory dishes and may not work as well in sweet baked goods.

Overall, ghee can be a good alternative to butter in some cases, but it may not be suitable for all recipes. For example, ghee may not work as well as butter in recipes that rely on the milk solids for structure or flavor, such as shortbread cookies or pastries

posts.com:
Dear shitki/ck/ers,

Have you ever noticed how a bite of food tastes significantly different when it's preassembled and shoved into your foodhole at the same time, versus when you chuck a couple things into your mouth in rapid succession? This has always baffled me, and, to be honest, as an atheist, is one of those little things that makes clear to me that we can never understand all of existence. Throw a piece of cheese on cracker and crunch that shit. It tastes Good. Now chuck that piece of cheese into your mouth and 0.5 seconds later toss in the cracker. It does not taste the same, and in my experience, it is almost always inferior to the bite where the ingredients arrive to your mouth all at the same time. Any hypotheses on this topic are welcome. >>18704249
I don't know of any chinese ground tea that's similar in quality to good matcha. It probably exists but I'd bet its in such small batches it's not worth seeking out. Japanese are more hyperfixated on doing things a certain way than the Chinese.

>for Chinese tea do you need those small 80ml cups?
Do you mean a gaiwan or the actual drinking cup?
You can drink tea out of whatever you like, though more neutral material like porcelain or glass is better. The idea of drinking out of a small cup is to influence the mouth feel and cool it down quicker so you can drink it faster and taste more. Certain cups exist to increase aroma, some focus more on cooling faster, really if you ever get into wanting a kind of cup it'll mostly be for aesthetics. Very few people really get several kinds of cups for different occasions, some people into tasting get smelling cups. I do find myself enjoying the flavor more out of my porcelain 60 ml cups more than my antique western style 6 oz teacups, but I use the 6 oz cup more because I don't have to use a gong dao bei.
>Impossible to make amounts like I'm used to with western teas if I want to go for quality?
eh, I typically get a bit more tea liquor out of gong fu brewing overall than if I used the same amount of leaf to brew western style. But at once? Yeah you're going to get less, but brew times are faster. I guess its more an active effort to taste tea than just western style drinking. I still mostly brew red tea in western style because the quality increase in gong fu is negligible unless I'm really in the mood for trying to find different notes.
Japanese tea is the annoying one. you only get 3, maybe 4, extractions and it's a higher leaf to water ratio than chinese, so it ends up costing more money for less tea. But japanese green tea is stupidly harsh on the stomach anyways so maybe its for the best it's harder to drink a liter of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18704336
Chinese tea culture is hyper casual so there's not really anything nearly as classy as a 4 hour long tea ceremony. Puerh is probably more or less the fancy stuff with the teapots designed around it and the culture of gifting it to your boss and such. But you still drink it with the same technique as anything else. I wouldn't put it even near the same category of flavors that matcha presents though, its just a completely different flavor profile and honestly its not very beginner friendly.
Chinese green teas have a different flavor overall from Japanese green teas, and that comes mostly from 2 factors; different cultivars and different processing. You can get into soil conditions as well but the other two are a bigger influence. Japanese have different tea tree cultivars that they'd bread for the qualities they want, chinese have their tea trees for the qualities they want. Japanese process via steaming and mostly do machine processing which cuts up the leaf more and increases surface area, Chinese process via dry heat and more by hand (due to cheap labor) so the leaf is more whole and has a different flavor profile. If you took a high quality Shincha and good Longjing, not even the most novice tea drinker could confuse them despite being both the most coveted highest quality greens in their respective countries. One is grassier with seaweed notes, one is tastes like roasted nuts.
Chinese and Japanese tea tastes don't overlap very much, and you can see that by what they drink. 90% of Japanese tea is green tea, Chinese is varied with Oolong probably having a slight edge.
Speaking of Oolong, it's probably going to be the best in class and taste without having to break into Puerh (though it's not the same flavor either). Oolong is somewhat fancy, given as gifts and growers have some pride in it, takes some technical skill to manufacture consistently. It can get rather pricey as well, but the mid shelf stuff at like $0.20 to $0.50 a gram is really good

Tasting notes:
2014 Jinggu Raw Puerh from LP (got in beginner pack)
probably the same thing as this but not barrel stored
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1097193078/2014-jinggu-raw-puerh-rye-barrel-stored

Parameters:
11g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with short steeps

Appearance: whole reddish brown leaves, medium size, moderate/dry storage, orange Liquor.

Notes:
Savory, grilled squash
Some smokiness
Herbaceous, old straw and hay
Tart, crab apple
Slight mineral aftertaste
Moderate bitterness and astringency, robust but not over powering.

Conclusion:
Reminds me a bit of a more refined higher quality semi aged XG toucha. It has got a similar robust smoky energy to it but the higher quality non-cut leaves (compared to cheap XG productions) means it is less likely to over brew into an acrid mess. If this were still for sale I would have recommend it as a good example of robust semi aged sheng.

Lp's cheaper cakes tend to be good deals if you live in the US and factor in shipping. That is a big part of the reason I mention them. Plus they won't take two months to get to you. The downside is that his selection is small and always changing so he does not always have cheap cakes in stock (they tend to sell out the fastest).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18723793
I'm using a 100ml gaiwan, boiling water. Started with a quick rinse then a ~20s first infusion, increased time with further infusions but wasn't tracking the time very precisely. First time I did 7 infusions and the second time I stopped at 3.
I'm terrible at at describing taste but I feel it kind of reminded me of the aftertaste of chocolate milk, and it was very smooth, which isn't what I usually expect out of tea.

It can take a while for me to learn to enjoy things, so I haven't entirely given up on it. I'll give it another gongfu attempt before trying grampa. If everything fails I'll try again in half a year when it's winter in the southern hemisphere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18723915
Sounds like you are brewing it the way i would, your description of the taste sounds about right.
I guese you can try using more tea and or pushing the steeps longer and see if you enjoy it with a more concentrated brew.
Also the grampa style i suggested. It will really hit its stride and give the most favor on the first refil so try and make it that far.
You can also try simmering it. 6.5 grams in 1.25 litres of water, low simmer for 15-20 minutes. That will also give you a very different flavor profile.
You also just might not like ripe, that's fine its not for everyone. Keep the cake around and try it again after 6 months or a year and see if your opinion changes at all.

>>18721642
The BRAT (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast) diet is the classic for helping through stomach upset, diarrhea, and nausea symptoms of any kind, and if it works it is a fine solution in the short term. While evidence in general on whether it is actually useful beyond just not being overpowering is rather weak, at least there's that. There are additional foods compatible with the general bland diet. A rundown on the recent specs on the diet and how to round it out, and where evidence is about at right now, is at https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/318255#other-foods-to-eat
As for making it more elaborate than just bananas on toast, or sweet potatoes on rice with a bit of salt, well, any recipe with seasoning or excess flavor, texture, or aroma will defeat the purpose of the diet. Start with the minimum your wife can tolerate, then maybe add a bit more texture, a dash of pepper here and there, and see how far you can go.

>Wife's pregnant and throwing everything up. Any recommendations on things to cook to keep her and our baby alive?
in some cases, it's just the way it goes...
nothing but crackers before noon.
If it's worse than that, and she's dehyrated, keep a case of electrolyte water in the house, like smartwater or pedialyte.
mint tea settles things for some people, and it's decaf.
pinch the fingers together, and look to see if the indentation stays flat. If it does, drink up, and realize room temp water goes down easier than warm or cold water.

If that doesn't work, might need IV fluids...but damn it's an awful time to walk into an ER or urgent care. They're all filled with covid, flu and RSV right now. My salmonella urgent care visit 2 days ago had like 80 ppl in the waiting room. It was more than 3hours, and I actually had an appointment.

posts.com:
First, soups can be a good option because they are easy to eat and can be made with a variety of nutrient-rich ingredients. Just try to stick with broth-based soups instead of cream-based ones, as they are usually easier on the stomach. Smoothies are another great choice because they allow you to get a lot of nutrients, including fruits, vegetables, and protein, in a form that is easy to digest. You can add things like avocado, nuts, or tofu to boost the protein content. Bananas are also a good source of potassium and are usually easy on the stomach. They can be eaten as a snack or used in recipes like smoothies or baked goods.

If your wife is experiencing nausea, crackers can be a good option because they can help to settle the stomach and provide a little bit of energy. Just try to choose crackers that are low in fat and sodium. If she's experiencing dehydration due to the vomiting, electrolyte drinks can help to replace lost fluids and minerals. You can find these at most grocery stores or pharmacies.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18680718
They produce a lot of snuffs under various sub-brands. I remember getting some "Jump" branded snuff in Austria several years ago, that was made by Poschl (I think it was an Austrian-market specific product). If you go to MrSnuff, you'll find they have a pretty wide variety of tinned snuffs. Unfortunately, I cannot order from them anymore (customs issues), and getting tobacco shipped from a continental online shop is an exercise in frustration and/or extreme patience.

I haven't tried many of their tinned snuffs, but I really liked Ozona President (which they apparently do not produce anymore, for some reason). Lowenprise is too cloying for my taste (too much anise). Gletscher Prise used to be good, but I think they changed the recipe, for the worse, a few years ago. Andechs Kloster is good, though some people might find it a bit too sweet. Gawith Apricot (yes, it's made by Poschl, despite carrying the name of a different snuff maker) is acceptable for a fruit-flavored snuff, the menthol helps rein in the apricot flavor's 'perfumy' tendencies.
Of the schmalzlers, I'd go for Sudfrucht (SF) and/or Doppelaroma (D), for that classic jamminess. However, Poschl schmalzlers are packed in sachets, and they tend to lose aroma if stored too long before use. You might occasionally get a dud. This is different from something like Bernard's Gekachelter Virginie, which is super harsh, very strong manure smell right out of the box, and actually benefits from air exposure to mellow out.

>>18688922

Yeah drying out can be a problem especially if you use snuff rather frequently ie. topping up multiple uses per session etc. and not cleaning properly which I would imagine is common among snuff users. I typically am a very moderate user however, keeping it mostly to 2-4 sniffs per day and don't have much of a problem with it. Also just to put it out there I blow and clean my nose grug style. Its a pretty private habit anyway since there aren't many users out there and I don't worry about it what people might think of it. Fact is its one of the healthiest and enjoyable ways to use tobacco, and last I checked the majority of our taste receptors are in the nasal cavity.

As one can imagine this is a dirt cheap habit. Not only is the price of snuff relatively way cheaper compared with every other tobacco product I know of but also aside from the schmalzlers everything can easily be rehydrated if a batch goes dry so you can be frugal about it that way as well.

soak unwashed rice 10 hours with a dash of salt in it

steam in a basket for 45 minutes

remove from heat, mix in lots of air and them compress into a puck

wrap in wet linen ttowel and let sit for 30 minutes

It’s always so unbelievable to me that people can’t cook rice. Next you’ll tell me you can’t boil pasta.

Here’s how to cook a single cup of rice. If you can’t manage this, just give up.

> bring 1 + 1/3 cup water to a boil
> add 1 cup rice, stir
> reduce heat to the lowest simmer possible, add lid to pot
> simmer for 10 minutes, with lid on, gently shake pot for first couple minutes (helps prevent boil over)
> remove from heat, keep covered for another five minutes
> wala

Also long grain rice = less sticky

I just posted this recently, but i will post it again. Perfect fluffy and firm rice out of the pot, texture is like fried rice.

>1 part basmati rice
>1 3/8 part water
>1 1/8 part lemon juice
>oil (preferably butter)
You want 1 1/2 part liquid total, with lemon juice to decrease stickiness. You could increase the lemon ratio for it to have noticeable flavor, which is good but not as versatile.

Rinse rice until water runs clear and soak for 30 minutes
Heat butter in a pot, drain rice, and toast it for a minute
Add lemon juice and water and let come to a boil

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Wash it and either
1) use less water or
2) boil a LOT of water, add the rice, and cook it like pasta, checking for doneness as it goes along and draining when it gets to the right texture

The second option is just about foolproof, so try that if the first doesn't pan out for you. Thankfully, rice is cheap and mushy rice can be repurposed into quite a number of other dishes like porridge/pudding, rice pie or blitzed with broth and vegetables to make s bisque.

>>18724568
You can work a lot of strong alcohol (doesn't have to be vodka, but there is cheap inoffensive vodka at Costco and TJ's, but you can use any strong spirit if you want some interesting flavor) into a sauce. Ital-American vodka sauce has an ideal balance point, but you could just keep going on top of that.
https://www.seriouseats.com/ask-the-food-lab-does-vodka-sauce-really-need-vodka
You can also use copious alcohol in combination with whatever you're using to turn a roux into a base sauce (so if it's roux+stock, then do 1/3 stock + 2/3 liquor), but if it's that early in the process then you want to choose a recipe that has minimal cook time once the sauce is made so that very little is let to evaporate.

Other options include mixing with coffee, hot chocolate, or learning to make any number of simple cocktails (all the simple ones are basically mixtures of citrus + sweetener + liquor, and the more citrus juice you add the less you'll taste the liquor)..

>>18725988
Inimitable, refreshing, sweet, with a delicate flavor, with sourness

It's the middle of fall, and it's cold. You just want to drink that fermented summer kvass, but it's out of season, right? Today we will tell you how to cook tasty and healthy substitute of this very kvass without spending money on chemicals from the stores. This is an ancient Russian drink — meat kvass. There are many recipes of meat kvass, now, and in Russia, too, each hostess had her own, but we will stop on this one. Well, let's begin.

1. Prepare the meat. Any kind will do, but not poultry, although, you can try. We can also use by-products. The meat should be well washed with water and put in a jar.

2. Boil water. For 500 grams of meat about 2 liters of water. After pouring boiling water over the meat, cover the jar with a cloth and leave it for 5 hours. This way the meat must infuse and acquire color and flavor.

3. Now add sugar. In general, I add 50 grams for each liter, but here it all depends on your taste. Then you have to put the kvass in a warm place for two weeks. Every day stir it and remove the resulting thick foam. It is important to keep the place dark, and the sun away from the fermenting kvass.

4. Strain the finished drink through gauze. Kvass can be stored in the refrigerator. Meat kvass is used for various cold soups. Do not throw out the meat in the jars. Add more fresh meat to it and you can make meat kvass again.

>Still, historians who have peeled the skin off this story have hastened to point out that Crum was not the sole inventor of the chip, or even the first. The earliest known recipe for chips dates to 1817, when an English doctor named William Kitchiner published The Cook’s Oracle, a cookbook that included a recipe for “potatoes fried in slices or shavings.”

>And in July 1849, four years before Crum supposedly dissed Vanderbilt, a New York Herald reporter noted the work of “Eliza,” also, curiously, a cook in Saratoga Springs, whose “potato frying reputation” had become “one of the prominent matters of remark at Saratoga.” Yet scholars are united in acknowledging that Crum popularized the chip. It was in Saratoga that the chips came into their own—today you can buy a version of Crum’s creations under the name Saratoga Chips—and in America that they became a culinary and commercial juggernaut.
Still seems to be main person responsible for bringing the dish into mainstream (at least as far restaurants menu appearances go) despite existing in prior incarnations in same way Ruth Graves Wakefield gets credit for the chocolate chip cookie despite broken up chocolate piece-cookies existing a lot prior.

posts.com:
It sounds like your grandmother may feel threatened or upset when you cook for her, possibly because she associates cooking with a time when she had to do it on her own and may feel like you are trying to take that role away from her. It is understandable that you want her to eat well and improve her diet, but it is important to approach the situation with sensitivity and respect for her feelings.

One possibility could be to involve your grandmother in the cooking process and offer to teach her some new recipes or techniques. This could give her a sense of accomplishment and allow her to learn something new, while also providing an opportunity for you to bond and spend time together. Alternatively, you could try suggesting that you cook together as a team, with each person contributing a dish or helping with different tasks.

If your grandmother is resistant to the idea of cooking or being involved in the process, it might be best to respect her wishes and find other ways to support her nutritional needs. You could consider bringing her prepared meals or offering to shop and bring her ingredients for healthy meals that she can prepare on her own. It might also be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with your grandmother about her feelings and concerns, and try to find a solution that works for both of you.

Please don't feel threatened by my cooking - I'm just trying to show you some love and care in a small way."

Ultimately, it's important to respect your grandmother's feelings and boundaries, and to be sensitive to the fact that she may have different emotional needs and triggers than you do. Try to approach the situation with empathy and understanding, and see if you can find a way to support her in a way that feels comfortable and meaningful for both of you.

It is generally recommended to consume alcohol in moderation, as excessive alcohol consumption can have negative health effects. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) defines moderate drinking as up to one drink per day for women and up to two drinks per day for men. A drink is defined as 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine, or 1.5 ounces of 80-proof distilled spirits.

>>18727384
While some people may try to save money by buying cheaper alcohol or drinking more frequently, it is important to consider the potential negative consequences of heavy alcohol consumption. In addition to the physical symptoms of hangovers, heavy alcohol use can also have financial, social, and legal consequences, such as lost productivity, strained relationships, and increased risk of accidents or injuries.

>>18727386

It is true that alcohol can be a social and cultural element of many events and gatherings, and can help people relax and loosen up in social situations. However, it is important to be mindful of how much alcohol you are consuming and to drink in moderation.

It is also important to consider the specific context and goals of the event or gathering. If you are attending a party or event where the focus is on heavy drinking, it may be more appropriate to choose lower-alcohol options or to drink in moderation. On the other hand, if the focus of the event is on socializing, conversation, or other activities, it may be more appropriate to choose lower-alcohol options or to drink in moderation to maintain clarity and focus.

>light beer pill
It's not healthy, but if you can make it work it's the lesser of a lot of evils. I couldn't do it, though. I'd either drink 30 light beers or I'd give up after a few and go get some malt liquor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here are a few ideas for how you can improve your chili:

Add more spices: In addition to salt, pepper, and crushed red peppers, consider adding other spices to your chili to give it more depth and flavor. Some options might include cumin, chili powder, paprika, oregano, and cayenne pepper.

Include more vegetables: Adding more vegetables to your chili can help to give it more depth and flavor. You can try adding diced bell peppers, onions, carrots, or zucchini to the pot.

Use better quality meat: Using high-quality ground beef chuck can make a big difference in the flavor and texture of your chili. Look for ground beef that is well-marbled with fat, as it will be more flavorful and tender.

Experiment with different types of beans: While kidney beans are a classic choice for chili, you could try using other types of beans as well. Black beans, pinto beans, and lentils are all good options.

Add some acidity: A little bit of acidity can help to balance out the rich, savory flavors in your chili. You can try adding a splash of vinegar or a squeeze of lime juice, or use diced tomatoes that are packed in tomato juice rather than water.

Experiment with different types of tomatoes: In addition to stewed and diced tomatoes, you can try using crushed tomatoes, tomato sauce, or tomato paste to give your chili a different flavor and texture.

I hope these suggestions are helpful! If you're looking for more ideas, you might also consider adding some diced green chilies, corn, or cooked grains like quinoa or bulgur to your chili.

chili powder. it's in the name. it's what makes chili chili.

my chili recipe
browned ground beef with onions or onion flakes
kidney beans
canned tomatoes
mushrooms (pieces and stems)
chili powder
cumin
salt
pepper
paprika
onion flakes
garlic powder
rice (cooked separately)

brown ground beef in a pan and either chop up onions or throw onion flakes in it, and season with salt and pepper while cooking. drain excess fat from the ground beef.

toss the ground beef and everything else except the rice in a crock pot. add water if the tomatoes don't have enough liquid. stir it all up and cook on low for 8 hours. then lower it to warm and let sit while making the rice in a rice cooker. when the rice is done scoop out some rice and scoop chili over the rice. enjoy.

Chili Con Carne
Yield: 8 quarts

>Bacon, 14 - 18 minced 1400 grams
>Onion, Yellow small dice 700 grams

>Chile Paste 300 grams
>Chili Seasoning 104 grams

>Salt, Diamond Kosher 40 grams

>Render minced bacon in rondeau over med-low heat until half cooked and bacon grease has rendered out, deglaze with little bit of beer and then strain into container to the side.
>Reintroduce enough bacon grease to bottom of rondeau and brown beef scraps and ground beef in bacon grease
>In a separate large pot, brown peppers and onions in tallow or bacon grease then introduce minced garlic. Deglaze with beer and then add browned beef, parcooked bacon, any leftover bacon grease, chili paste, and chili seasoning
>Let seasoning/paste cook into meat for 20 mins
>Add fire roasted tomato and rest of beer, bring to simmer and let reduce for 1 hour
>Turn off heat, stir in salt, then season to taste

3/3

posts.com:
There are two ways.
A. Procedural
Start with dried BEANS, canned ones have already been cooked at far too high a heat and will turn to shit. I recommend pressure cooking your own rehydrated beans, this is also far cheaper.

Ground beef often has too much fat to sear, don't be scared to pour that fat off then add it back in with the onions.

Use whole spice, fry the whole spice off in vegetable oil, then either blend the mixture or just use the oil. This is unfamiliar to Americans but Indians and Chinese understand you get more value and fresher spices. Again add this with the onions and you speed up the cooking time.

Add the beans after the onions are done, this avoids over cooking your beans.

Add stock rather than water.
I boil beef bones then ladle the stock in as the chili reduces so it's not dry. This adds nutrition and means you can use less ground beef.

B. Ingredients
Whole spice is always preferable.
Don't buy meat which was butchered 5 days ago then pumped full of water, or mince that's half fat, the fat will merely stop you getting a good sear and float to the top as an oil slick.

When it comes to tomatoes make sure you're buying sauce tomatoes to make sauce. You may find passata is a better option, only use tomato paste if you can't get sauce tomatoes or is significantly cheaper.

Cinnamon lifts a chili up, so does bay leaf. Go easy on the garlic.

Remember onions are for flavor, huge flavorless onions make a sweet, flavorless chili. All things being equal buy shallottes, there's nothing wrong with wild onions or a mix of different onions.

Don't chili corn. It's shit and if you really want corn add it when serving otherwise again you're just boiling the sugar out of it.

>inb4 buthurt about not using a single pot
>inb4 buthurt from Texan autists

>>18727150

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Also the same rules for hard spice apply to chili. Use fresh chili with onions, failing that blend whole dried chillies (don't fry them off just drop them into the hot oil before blending) failing that chili flakes. There is no excuse for using chili powder.

Never add pre made hot sauce. You're cooking, remember? Don't add table condiments as ingredients.
Don't cook with cheese, cheese is best added when serving. Cheese is expensive and boiling the dairy fats out of it only adds to the oil slick.

Rice never goes in a chili, you serve rice as a side. Cooking it creates a clag of starch and makes reheating a pain and freezing a waste.
If you want to make chili as if it was a Spanish Paella you would have to cook the whole thing like a paella and at that point.

It's totally acceptable to cook chili in a clay pot/tangine/ Dutch oven. This works well if your using rehydrated beans but not preassure cooking. If you're using whole beefs like a mole it's actually the best way.

Some people prefer a lighter chili with chicken stock, white beans, or chicken. In this case see: cassoulette, French one pot chicken with beans.
Cooking this like a chili will just string out your chicken.
>unami bombing
Cheese, soya sauce, stock powder, excessive tomato paste, fish sauce etc.
What you crave is MSG and you may as well add it pure and avoid polluting your chili further. If this is you then remember MSG is instantly soluble and to reduce salt by 1/3.

If you cook raw beans in tomato sauce the acid fucks with them, some people prefer this but if you're not happy with the texture of your beans try boiling them separately, discarding the liquid, adding them later. Or preassure cook.

Never add salt, msg, or any other soluble mineral prior to reducing. It shits me to tears how many people don't know this and how many chefs persist in this. It's not a matter of purism nor is it pedantic. You either are overstalting all your sauce, risk doing so for no reason.

>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18728679
It's generally not recommended to caramelize eggs because the high heat and long cooking time required to caramelize food can cause the eggs to become tough and rubbery. Soft and snotty, or soft and runny, eggs are typically preferred in dishes like scrambled eggs or sunny-side up eggs.
Caramelization is a cooking technique that involves heating sugar or other carbohydrates to a high temperature until they turn brown and develop a rich, complex flavor. This process works well with certain ingredients like meat, onions, and dairy products, but not all ingredients benefit from caramelization.
Different ingredients have different properties and respond differently to different cooking techniques, so it's important to choose the right techniques for the ingredients you're working with. In the case of eggs, it's generally better to use a gentler cooking method like poaching or frying to achieve the desired texture and flavor.

Here are some affordable staples that can be used to make a variety of meals:

Rice (such as white rice, brown rice, wild rice)
Pasta (such as spaghetti, penne, fettuccine)
Dried beans (such as black beans, kidney beans, chickpeas, lentils)
Canned beans (such as black beans, kidney beans, chickpeas, lentils)
Frozen vegetables (such as broccoli, peas, carrots, green beans, mixed vegetables)
Canned vegetables (such as tomatoes, corn, green beans, mixed vegetables)
Canned fruit (such as pineapple, peaches, pears, mixed fruit)
Dried fruit (such as raisins, apricots, cranberries, figs)
Oats (such as old-fashioned oats, quick oats, steel-cut oats)
Whole grain bread
Whole grain cereal (such as oats, corn flakes, bran flakes)
Nuts (such as almonds, peanuts, cashews, walnuts)
Seeds (such as sunflower seeds, pumpkin seeds, chia seeds, flax seeds)
Tofu
Canned fish (such as salmon, tuna, sardines)
Low-sodium broth (such as chicken broth, beef broth, vegetable broth)
Canned soups (such as tomato soup, chicken noodle soup, minestrone)
Peanut butter
Nut butters (such as almond butter, cashew butter)
Jam or jelly
Honey
Maple syrup
Olive oil
Vegetable oil
Vinegar (such as red wine vinegar, white vinegar, apple cider vinegar)
Soy sauce
Worcestershire sauce
Mustard (such as yellow mustard, Dijon mustard)
Mayonnaise
Hot sauce
Dried herbs (such as basil, oregano, thyme, rosemary)
Dried spices (such as cumin, paprika, chili powder, turmeric)
By keeping these staples on hand, you'll have a wide range of ingredients to choose from when planning your meals. You can use them to make everything from stir-fries and soups to sandwiches, salads, and grain bowls. These staples are non-perishable, which means they have a longer shelf life and can be stored in your pantry or cupboard for an extended period of time.

Here are some affordable staples that can be used to make a variety of meals:

Rice: Rice is a staple in many cultures and is relatively inexpensive. It can be used as a base for dishes like stir-fries, fried rice, and rice bowls.
Pasta: Pasta is another affordable staple that can be used to make a variety of dishes, such as pasta sauces, macaroni and cheese, and pasta salads.
Potatoes: Potatoes are a cheap and versatile ingredient that can be used to make dishes like mashed potatoes, roasted potatoes, and potato soup.
Beans: Beans are an affordable source of protein and can be used to make dishes like chili, burritos, and bean salads.
Canned tomatoes: Canned tomatoes are a convenient and affordable way to add flavor and nutrition to a variety of dishes, including soups, stews, and pasta sauces.
Eggs: Eggs are a cheap and versatile ingredient that can be used to make dishes like omelets, frittatas, and scrambled eggs.
Frozen vegetables: Frozen vegetables are a convenient and affordable option for adding nutrition to your meals. They can be used to make stir-fries, soups, and casseroles.
Peanut butter: Peanut butter is a cheap and nutritious ingredient that can be used to make sandwiches, dips, and sauces.
Chicken breasts: Chicken breasts are a relatively inexpensive source of protein that can be used to make dishes like chicken stir-fries, grilled chicken, and chicken salad.
Ground beef: Ground beef is an affordable source of protein that can be used to make dishes like burgers, meatballs, and tacos.

basic staples:
Flour
sugar(cane like zulka is best)
yeast
baking powder, baking soda
eggs
pastas
canned tomatoes, diced, stewed, crushed and paste
onions
carrots
potatoes
winter squash like acorn, spaghetti
several bags of frozen vegetables you like, Cali mix, peas...
a large bag of jasmine rice
Several 1-2 pound bags of dried beans, lentils
Tortillas, bread/buns
A good selection of spices: Basic bitch starter of Salt, pepper (in grinder), garlic powder, onion powder, cumin, cayenne, turmeric basil, Italian seasoning, season salt of your choice(s)**You will build this up as you go,
Olive oil, NOT from Italy, small jar of coconut oil,butter
Cheeses of choice--I like to keep pizza cheeses, sharp cheddar, a package of slices of swiss or american and a have a good cheese grater(the pre shredded is fine to begin with, but It's way better to grate your own)
soy sauce
a good vinegar you like and would use on salad--Apple cider, rice wine, or balsamic
2-4 hot sauces, if you like spicy, it's good to have a selection with different "bodies" like crystal, sriracha, valentina and sambal
and everything else gets purchased as you go--
Welcome to the wonderful world of planning ahead.
It's a gets lot easier as you go, and is 10 gorrilion times better for you.
Don't forget to get some decent storage containers or ziplocks.
Also: get a good pouch of catnip for kitty--it'll keep his--nope HER tail outta yer bait...I mean dinner.

>>18724602
>>18724053

It turned out okay. I think my convection oven runs hotter than its dial so I set it for 250, for one hour and half, for the 3.2 lbs leg. I checked the internal temperature after one hour and it was at 95 ish so I thought to myself it should be good for another half an hour, but I was wrong, the second time that I checked, the temperature was already at 140. I was too scared to blast it at 500 after that so we just carved it and it was really tender despite it being almost well done.

The flavour was much milder than I expected, very little gamey taste but I can also just barely taste the rub. I also couldn’t taste the cumin. Either I added too little or they burnt. It was well received by my family and we already finished half of it while there’s other meat dishes on the table. The text time that I’ll make it, I’ll probably upscaled the rub by another 1/3 and check the temperature a second time after 1h15m.

If you're really scared you can turn off the heat and let it cool down completely, then put the heat on really low and constantly stir until you've got a nice goopy consistency. It's slow, it takes patience, but it's also really hard to fuck up so for you now the trade-off is worth it. In time you'll get a bead on the heat you need and the consistency you're looking for once you make it enough.

Other then that just make sure your ratios are right friend. Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are a few reasons why carbonara can be tricky to make. One reason is that it requires the eggs to be cooked to the right consistency, which can be difficult to achieve if you're not careful. The eggs should be just cooked, but not scrambled, so it's important to temper them properly. To do this, you can slowly drizzle in a little bit of the hot pasta water while whisking the eggs and cheese together. This will help to cook the eggs gently and create a smooth, creamy sauce.

Another reason carbonara can be difficult is that it's easy to overcook the pasta. The pasta should be cooked to al dente, which means it should still have a little bit of bite to it. Overcooking the pasta can cause it to become mushy, which can ruin the texture of the dish.

Finally, it's important to use good quality ingredients in your carbonara. The pasta should be high-quality semolina flour pasta, and the eggs and cheese should be fresh and of good quality. Using fresh ingredients will help to ensure that your carbonara turns out flavorful and delicious.

I hope these tips help! If you're still having trouble, it may be helpful to look for a recipe or video tutorial that demonstrates the steps for making carbonara.

Tuna: Tuna is a classic choice for sandwiches, and it's often used in tuna salad sandwiches or tuna melts.

Chicken: Canned chicken is a good option for sandwiches because it's easy to shred and can be used in a variety of recipes, such as chicken salad sandwiches or chicken salad wraps.

Ham: Canned ham is a convenient option for sandwiches, and it's often used in ham and cheese sandwiches or ham salad sandwiches.

Turkey: Canned turkey is another popular choice for sandwiches, and it can be used in a variety of recipes, such as turkey and cheese sandwiches or turkey salad sandwiches.

Salmon: Canned salmon is a good option for sandwiches, and it can be used in recipes like salmon salad sandwiches or salmon burgers.

Ultimately, the best canned meat for sandwiches will depend on your personal preference. Experiment with different types of canned meats to find the one that you like the most.

posts.com:
I love soup, bros.
>keeps you warm in the cold months, cold soups keep you cool in the heat
>doesn't rely on cooking the ingredients until most of their moisture is gone, wasting the water that went into their production and not helping you stay hydrated
>almost everything just stays in the pot from start to finish, so the broth retains all the nutrients that other recipes would discard
>allows you to use damn near anything in your pantry and fridge
>scales up in an easy way, so you can use up ingredients going bad or large amounts of produce you got from a friend with no problem
>can be frozen and kept for later
>every culture has dozens of soups, so you will never run out of options
The only flaw I can think of is that reheating soup is slower than for most other foods, and that's very minor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18715104
Canned cream soups are usually bottom tier shit, typically unflavored, salty, and thin or cheap on ingredients (or all of the above).

Restaurants can be low on ingredients too, though the higher end ones will be a bit better.

Properly made cream soups are fantastic. Also if you make it yourself YOU control the thickness of the soup, so you can dial it in to match your preferences: thinner or thiccer. Plus you can cream a soup with any starch, not just flour. Potato, rice, etc.

To make a cream soup: start with a roux, which is just butter and flour, then cook it for a bit while whisking, then add cream or milk in slowly. Let it absorb and keep adding until you go from thicc to as thin as you want. Then add ingredients to the soup. Crab and old bay for cream of crab, clams for clam chowder, ham and potato for cream of ham, and so on.

>>18717183
Hand blender.

Very easy.
Three large leeks, greens chopped from white, save greens. Three medium sized russet potatoes peeled cut into large chunks.

After washing leeks, roughly chop whites, and roast greens in oven with a large carrot.

Meanwhile Sautee down whites with two chopped celery ribs, and four large garlic cloves in about 3 tbs of butter.

When leeks and garlic have started to just brown, add in 2 tsp of mustard powder, tsp of b pepper, 2 tsp of dried tarragon, mix well, and add in a tablespoon of ap flour.

Cook for a bit and then add two and a half liters or about a gallon of chicken stock, the potatoes, the roasted greens, simmer down under potatoes are soft and liquid is about 3 / 4 what it used to be.

When potatoes are done, remove the leek green, and hand blend the soup, adjust seasoning, and then incorporate a cup of 10% cream. Let sit over night for best flavor.

Sounds complicated, but good soups involve layering and steps. Good luck!

Pound two teaspoons of tamarind, six red chillies, six cloves of garlic, a teaspoon of mustard seed, a salt-spoonful of fenugreek seed, twelve black peppercorns, 1/4 teaspoon of salt, and six curry leaves.
When worked to a paste, add a pint of water, and boil the mixture for 15 minutes. While this is going on, cuts up two small onions, put them into a pot, and fry them in two teaspoons of ghee till they begin to turn brown, then strain the pepper-water into the pot, and cook the mixture for five minutes, after which it is ready.

posts.com:
There could be several reasons why your apple loaf bread was gooey. Here are a few potential explanations:

The amount of moisture in the recipe: If you added a lot of moist ingredients (like the apples and apple sauce) and not enough dry ingredients (like flour), the bread may have turned out too moist and gooey.
The baking time and temperature: If the bread was not baked for long enough or at the right temperature, it may have remained gooey in the middle.
The type of flour you used: Oat flour is more absorbent than all-purpose flour, so it may not have provided enough structure to the bread. Using a different type of flour, such as all-purpose or whole wheat, could help the bread hold its shape better.
It's also possible that the recipe you were following had an error or that there were other factors at play that affected the outcome of your bread. If you're having trouble getting the bread to turn out correctly, you may want to try a different recipe or consult a baking guide for more guidance.

Any baking pros here that can help me adjust this recipe?

I've been working on an Italian Lemon Ricotta Cake for Christmas and it's just not quite where I want it to to be yet.

I'm making it in a bundt cake pan so I cut about 10 minutes off the bake time and it came out good but a bit darker than I wanted, and dryer towards the edges.
Should I take off more time or more heat?

Even the moist part was a bit less wet/cheesecakey than I am going for.
What can I change to bump up the wet/moist/denseness just a bit without ruining the lightness?

I see a lot of recipes for this cake using regular flour instead of cornstarch.
How would that change how the cake turns out?

Also, this is supposed to have a glaze but I want something less sweet.
Is there something I can find a recipe for that's halfway between a frosting and a whipped cream?

Original Recipe:
>300 g ricotta
>100 g sugar
>40 g butter
>3 eggs

Here are some suggestions for adjusting the recipe:

To reduce the bake time and prevent the cake from getting too dark, you can try reducing the oven temperature to 325°F or even 300°F. You could also try covering the top of the cake with foil after it has been in the oven for a while to prevent it from getting too dark.

To make the cake moister and more dense, you could try increasing the amount of ricotta or adding some sour cream or yogurt to the batter. You could also try adding some extra egg yolks to the batter to make it more rich and creamy.

If you want to use regular flour instead of cornstarch, you can use all-purpose flour in place of the cornstarch. The texture of the cake may be slightly denser and less fluffy, but it should still work well.

For a glaze that is less sweet, you could try making a simple syrup by boiling equal parts sugar and water until the sugar is dissolved, and then brushing it with lemon juice or another citrus juice. You could then drizzle the syrup over the cake. Alternatively, you could try making a whipped cream topping by whipping heavy cream with a little sugar and vanilla extract until stiff peaks form.

posts.com:
Using lime juice in place of lemon juice in chocolate chip cookies is generally acceptable, although it will alter the flavor of the cookies slightly. Lemon juice has a distinct, tangy flavor that is often used to add a hint of sourness to baked goods, while lime juice has a slightly sweeter, more tropical flavor. If you use lime juice in place of lemon juice in your chocolate chip cookie recipe, the cookies may have a slightly different taste than you are used to.

That being said, the amount of lemon juice typically used in chocolate chip cookie recipes is relatively small, so the flavor of the cookies will not be greatly affected. If you are a fan of the flavor of lime and want to try using it in your chocolate chip cookies, go ahead and give it a try. You may find that you prefer the taste of lime-infused cookies to those made with lemon juice. Just be prepared for a slightly different flavor profile.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18728181
Yes, it is acceptable to use lime juice in place of lemon juice when making chocolate chip cookies. Lime juice has a similar sour and acidic taste to lemon juice, and it can be used as a substitute in recipes that call for lemon juice. However, keep in mind that lime juice will add a distinct lime flavor to the cookies, which may or may not be desired depending on your taste preferences. If you prefer a more subtle flavor, you may want to use a smaller amount of lime juice or consider using another acid, such as vinegar or cream of tartar, as a substitute.

Try using different types of bread, such as sourdough, rye, or pumpernickel.
Experiment with different types of cheese, such as cheddar, gouda, or brie.
Add some vegetables, such as tomato slices, onions, or bell peppers.
Spread some condiments on the bread before grilling, such as mayonnaise or mustard.

I hope these suggestions inspire you to try some new variations on the classic grilled cheese sandwich!

Cake:
1 cups (150) all-purpose flour
1/3 cup (45g) cocoa powder

1/3 tsp (1.3g) baking soda
1/3 cup (70g) brown sugar
1/2 cup (110g) castor white sugar
1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil
2 large eggs
1/2 Tbsp (6g) vanilla extract
double shot of Lambs spiced rum
1 cup single cream (brought to a light simmer)

bake in 2 6" bottom free cake tins lined with
baking paper for 30min at 170c

1/2 cup (55g) cocoa powder

1/2 Tbsp (6g) vanilla extract
double shot of Lambs spiced rum
cream to thin 1/4 cup

Garnish
7 rum truffles
grated 90% chocolet
